anchor.surface_text: The question, therefore, is number whether the order of the Tribunal in so far as it related to the interest income was made by inadvertence or under a mistake, but whether the Income-tax Officer companyld initiate proceedings over again under s. 34 of the Act in derogation of the finding given by the Tribunal that the Income-tax Officer did number discover that the income had escaped assessment.

anchor.surface_text: though there was a finding by the Tribunal that the Income-tax Officer did number discover that there was escape of assessment,. the Income-tax Officer under the amended s. 34 can initiate proceedings in spite of that finding. We cannot accept this argument.

arguments.claim: The Tribunal order dated April 25, 1949 set aside the entire reassessment order as ITO did not come into possession of definite information under s.34, covering both forest and interest income.

arguments.claim: The Income-tax Act is a self-contained code creating hierarchy of tribunals; Tribunal orders final subject to s.66; cannot reopen except under ss.34/35 within time.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Act is a self-contained one. It creates a hierarchy of tribunals with original, appellate and revisional jurisdictions. Section 31 gives... orders passed by the Appellate Tribunal on appeal shall be final.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal's final order on lack of discovery under s.34 binds ITO; no s.35 rectification or s.66 reference taken; prevents circumvention via fresh s.34 notice.

holdings.text: The legal effect of the order was that the re-assessment of the entire income, including the forest income and interest income, was set aside on the ground that the Income-tax Officer did not come into possession of definite information leading to a discovery and, therefore, he could not initiate proceedings under s. 34 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amended s.34(1)(a) 'reason to believe' due to non-disclosure does not override prior final Tribunal finding of ITO knowledge/no discovery; implies no such belief possible.

holdings.text: The order of the Tribunal made within its jurisdiction, subject to the provisions of s. 66 of the Act, is final.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from the said provisions that the order of the Tribunal made within its jurisdiction, subject to the provisions of s. 66 of the Act, is final.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Income-tax Act creates hierarchy with finality for Tribunal orders except reference under s.66; self-contained code exhausts remedies.

holdings.text: Final assessment cannot be reopened except in the circumstances detailed in Sections 34 and 35 of the Act and within the time limited by those sections.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tar, Bombay Aden v. Khemchand Ramdas 1

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tar, Bombay Aden v. Khemchand Ramdas 1  succinctly stated the legal position thus But it is number true that after a final assessment under those sections  ss. 23 and 29  has been made, the Income-tax Officer can go on making fresh companyputations and issuing fresh numberices of demand to the end of all time But when once a final assessment is arrived at, it cannot in Their Lordships opinion be reopened except in the circumstances detailed in  1   1938  6 I.T.R. 414, 424, 426.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay & Aden v. Khemchand Ramdas
precedents.cited_proposition: Once a final assessment is made, it cannot be reopened except in the circumstances detailed in Sections 34 and 35 of the Act; the provisions are exhaustive and prescribe the only circumstances and time for fresh assessments.
precedents.cited_holding: But when once a final assessment is arrived at, it cannot in Their Lordships opinion be reopened except in the circumstances detailed in Sections 34 and 35 of the Act and within the time limited by those sections.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, West Punjab v. The Tribune Trust, Lahore 1

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax, West Punjab v. The Tribune Trust, Lahore 1 , after numbericing the relevant sections of the Act, reaffirmed the same position and held that assessments once made would be valid and effective until they were set aside in the manner prescribed by the Act and that, if number so set aside, they were final. 1 1941 16 I.T.R. 214.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, West Punjab v. Tribune Trust, Lahore
precedents.cited_proposition: Assessments once made are valid and effective until set aside in the manner prescribed by the Act; if not so set aside, they are final.
precedents.cited_holding: assessments once made would be valid and effective until they were set aside in the manner prescribed by the Act

precedents.case_name: K. Das & Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: Income-tax Officer cannot make reassessment unless prescribed notice issued in valid form; if notice bad due to lack of sanction, returns filed pursuant to it are also bad.
